refnamediv.refpurpose: Prints human-readable information about a variable

refsect1.title: Description

note.simpara: The return parameter was added in PHP 4.3.0

refsect1.simpara: print_r displays information about a variable in a way that's readable by humans. If given a string, integer or float, the value itself will be printed. If given an array, values will be presented in a format that shows keys and elements. Similar notation is used for objects.
Remember that print_r will move the array pointer to the end. Use reset to bring it back to beginning.
refsect1.para:
Which will output: 
Array
(
    [a] => apple
    [b] => banana
    [c] => Array
        (
            [0] => x
            [1] => y
            [2] => z
        )
)
If you would like to capture the output of print_r, use the return parameter. If this parameter is set to &true;, print_r will return its output, instead of printing it (which it does by default).

example.title: return parameter example
example.programlisting: <?php $b = array ('m' => 'monkey', 'foo' => 'bar', 'x' => array ('x', 'y', 'z')); $results = print_r ($b, true); //$results now contains output from print_r ?>

note.simpara: If you need to capture the output of print_r with a version of PHP prior to 4.3.0, use the output-control functions.

Prior to PHP 4.0.4, print_r will continue forever if given an array or object that contains a direct or indirect reference to itself. An example is print_r($GLOBALS) because $GLOBALS is itself a global variable that contains a reference to itself.

refsect1.simpara: See also ob_start, var_dump, and var_export.
